Subject: Unicode Proposal
Date: Sun, 23 Sep 2007 13:25:47 -0400
From: Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...>
To: Read_alphabet@yahoogroups.com


amd64_hacker:

Regarding your Unicode Proposal.  First let me thank you for myself and the group for your willingness to put your effort and time into this for us all. 

I had not found the time to look your proposal in detail previously.  Here are my thoughts.

First, a couple of minor things:

At the beginning of the proposal, there is a duplicated "with."

    A caseless, phonetic, left-to-right alphabet optimised for the
    English language (but still useful for other languages with
    similar sounds) created by (Ronald) Kingsley Read.  It is
    the successor to and has much in common with with Shavian.
    Authoritative documentation for it can be found in â€œThe
    QuikScript Alphabetâ€�. [emphasis added]

In the following paragraph under "Alternate Forms," I suggest changing the word "usually" to "highly" since some letters can be properly connected and some cannot.

    Many letters have half height or alternate forms in order to help
    speed up writing by reducing the number of strokes and pen lifts.
    The half height and alternate forms are only used in â€˜seniorâ€™
    QuikScript which is usually cursive. [emphasis added]

Whether a given writer decides to connect any letter to another is his choice, but I would consider it improper to extend or change the form of a letter in order to make a connection to the next letter possible.  I believe the only exceptions approved by Read in the QS manual are for the letters with alternate forms (N-o and U-tter) and for F-ee, M-ay and TH-ey.

The alternate "TH-ey" extends the bottom of the letter upwards to the lower writing line to permit connection with the next letter.  Read terms this an "allowable extension," but it seems to me it should be considered an alternate form and listed that way in the proposal.  While the end stroke of F-ee can also be extended to join the next letter, that seems less important to me so, in my opinion, it could be left out of the proposal.  Of course, others may feel that it should be included.  I don't know how difficult it is to include these from a technical standpoint.  If we make provision for some alternate forms, then adding a couple more is probably no big deal.  In looking back at the manual for the first time in a long time, I realize that I almost habitually use the alternate form of "M-ay."  The standard form seems a little more difficult for me to write.  That may be lack of practice or it may have something to do with being left-handed.

I am confused about your list of letters presented as having half-height forms.  You list 15 such letters, but the QS manual lists only P-ea, T-ea, H-e, D-ay, Z-oo, and W-ay.  In addition to those, I have used WH-y and Y-e for decades since they work as half-letters just as well as the six Read suggested.  I had actually forgotten they are not listed in the manual as half-letters until Jon Zuck pointed it out to me.  Since it is clear what letters they are, it just made sense to me.  Besides, I love the way the half-letters contribute to the variety of wordshapes possible in QS.  However, you have added seven more:  F-ee, V-ie, S-ee, SH-e, J'-ai, CH-eer, J-ay.  I believe this is incorrect.  Can you explain how they can be used as half-height forms?

I have never used the two "x" letters as they always struck me as outside the spirit of QS -- 1 phoneme to 1 symbol.  It was Read's stated goal for "x" to "compete" with the TO "x" as if that was necessary to avoid people deciding that QS was not viable because of two instances where it took two QS symbols when only one was needed in TO.  Should "x" be included in the proposal.  It is in the manual, and I guess that if it is coded, then people can choose whether to use it or not.

I'm impressed with the rest of the proposal.  Thank you again for working on this.

Paige
